tossups.question: Oxazines are hydrolysed to compounds containing this functional group in the Meyers synthesis. A compound containing one of these functional groups is reacted with an organozinc halide in the Fukuyama coupling. The bond central to this functional group exhibits a strong stretch corresponding to an IR peak between (*) 1600 and 1900 inverse centimeters. Compounds with this functional group can be oxidized with a peroxyacid to form an ester in the Baeyer-Villiger synthesis. Primary or secondary alcohols are produced by reduction of these compounds by Grignard reagents. For 10 points, name this functional group that consists of a carbon double bonded to an oxygen.
tossups.answer: carbonyl [anti-prompt on ketone, aldehyde, or thioester]

tossups.question: This leader’s critic J. M. Kariuki was found dead after entering a Hilton in the company of this leader’s bodyguard. This leader’s wife, Mama Ngina, amassed great wealth during his time in power, and was thought to be involved in ivory smuggling. Rawson Macharia testified that this leader required him to strip naked, walk through an arch of banana leaves seven times, and drink (*) blood during the administration of an oath. This leader’s country became a one-party state after he outlawed the KPU, founded by his former vice president Oginga Odinga. This leader, who was tried as part of the Kapenguria Six after the Mau Mau rebellion, was succeeded by Daniel Arap Moi. For 10 points, name this author of Facing Mount Kenya, who served as the first President of Kenya.
tossups.answer: Jomo Kenyatta [or Kamau wa Ngengi; or Johnstone Kamau] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: In one exhibition, YBA artists Jake and Dinos Chapman “defaced” prints of this artist’s work with cheeky doodles. This painter showed his own calling card in the beak of a pet magpie in a portrait called the “Red Boy.” This artist’s wife and his maid Leocadia Weiss looked so similar that it can be difficult to tell portraits of them apart. This artist, who painted four men in dunce caps in The Inquisition Tribunal, created a set of rather anticlerical etchings called his (*) Caprices, including one which shows a swarm of owls and bats tormenting a sleeping man. This artist of The Sleep of Reason Produces Monsters created another series of etchings depicting the injustices of the Peninsular War. For 10 points, identify this Spanish artist who showed a white-shirted man in front of a firing squad in The Third of May 1808.
tossups.answer: Francisco Goya [or Francisco José de Goya y Lucientes] <DS>

tossups.question: Harold Black is most famous for his work with these devices. The parametric type of these devices uses a varactor to achieve remarkably low noise. A type of this device which exploits the orthogonality of sine functions in order to select for a reference signal is called the “lock-in” type. AGC is a technique used with these devices to automatically attain a steady output. If one of these devices operates its components in a switched instead of linear fashion, then it is (*) Class-D. The common-mode rejection ratio is a figure of merit for the differential type of these devices, and the ideal operational type of these devices has infinite differential gain. For 10 points, name these devices that increase the intensity of a signal.
tossups.answer: amplifier [accept more specific answers like operational amplifier, lock-in amplifier, differential amplifier, etc.]

tossups.question: A sickly yellow set was designed by Edvard Munch for one production of this play. This play was described as “an open drain; a loathsome sore unbandaged” in one of the many negative critical reviews excerpted in George Bernard Shaw’s essay on the “Quintessence” of its author. In this play, one character’s only memory of his father is of being forced to smoke a pipe until he became sick. One character in this play describes a (*) fire as judgment upon the central family, but is later accused of starting it himself. The main character of this play conceals her husband’s illegitimate daughter Regina as her maid, leading her own son to become attracted to his half-sister. For 10 points, name this play in which Helene discovers that Oswald has inherited his father’s syphilis, a work by Henrik Ibsen.

After this politician was sent as part of a three-man delegation to investigate contested elections in Kansas, he wrote most of the Howard Report. During an election for Speaker of the House, this politician was attacked for endorsing Hinton Helper’s book The Impending Crisis of the South. This politician’s own campaign manager, James Garfield, emerged as the eventual nominee in the 1880 Republican National Convention. This politician drafted, and later carried out, the 1875 Resumption Act, which restored the(*) gold standard. This politician introduced a law that ended the minting of silver coins called the Crime of ‘73, and is the namesake of a 1890 Silver Purchase Act. For 10 points, a law named after Clayton strengthened what Republican politician’s namesake Antitrust Act?

This leader confiscated a place that his people previously shared half-and-half with Jews, called Fadak. Because he thought a potential future leader would be too harsh, Talha famous objected to a decision made by this leader. One sect believes that this figure sent Khalid ibn Walid to lead a corps that would fight against tribes such as the Azd. The (*) riddah, or apostasy, was suppressed by this figure, who offered a camel to a man for free, but discovered that man would only pay full price. After that incident, this man accompanied a prophet on a trip to Medina. Muhammad married this man’s daughter Aishah, and Umar succeeded, for 10 points, what supposed first free male convert to Islam, who some Muslims consider the first caliph?
tossups.answer: Abu Bakr as-Siddiq Abdallah bin Abi Quḥafah <HB>

tossups.question: A group of scientists led by Jef Boeke and Joel Bader are changing all the TAG [T-A-G] stop codons in this organism’s genome into TAA [T-A-A], in hopes of eventually synthetically generating an entire modified genome for this organism. In this organism, the dephosphorylase Mih1[M-I-H-one] and the kinase Swe1 [Swee-one] fight over the phosphorylation status of Cdc28 during the G2-M checkpoint. The SWI/SNF [switch-sniff] nucleosome remodelling complex was first discovered in this organism. (*) Cub and Nub domains are used in a variant of a technique first applied in this organism, their namesake “two-hybrid” screen. This organism was the first eukaryote to have its genome entirely sequenced. When these organisms mate, they form a shmoo between the two sexes, a and alpha. For 10 points, name this budding yeast used in brewing and baking.
tossups.answer: Saccharomyces cerevisiae [prompt on Saccharomyces; prompt on yeast or baker’s yeast or brewer’s yeast until “yeast” is read]

tossups.question: In 2001, after a Constitutional Court banned a political party in this nation, a party based on the so-called National Vision, known as the Felicity Party, was formed. A former prime minister of this country instituted a “Zero Problems with the Neighbors” foreign policy, and one party leader in this country is nicknamed after a mythical she-wolf. A CNN interview with this country’s current leader was given via (*) FaceTime, and that leader’s security detail attacked a crowd of demonstrators in Washington, DC. That leader of this country referred to the Dutch government as “fascist remnants” because they wouldn’t let him campaign for a referendum in their country. This country was briefly led by Abdullah Gul, and a coup attempt in this country was called the work of the exiled Fethullah Gulen. For 10 points, name this country led by Recep Erdogan [“air-do-waan”].

A song named for a person with this word in his name features Quavo rapping “I pull up with blazers, Portland” and a hook that begins “I done put 20 inside the sig.” One song named for this brand contains the line “your mom still live in a tent” and a reference to its rapper being kicked off a commercial airliner for being high on percocets. Lil Pump has this brand’s logo tattooed on his chest, and his most recent song is titled after a (*) “gang” named for this brand. Kreayshawn’s biggest hit repeats the name of this brand at the beginning of its refrain. An Atlanta rapper named for this brand inspired Fetty Wap’s stage name, and has released several albums titled Trap House. That man adopted the persona “Guwop” for several songs. For 10 points, name this Italian luxury clothing brand, whose logo is two interlocking Gs.
tossups.answer: Gucci [on first line, accept Gucci Mane or Guwop] <JM> Editor’s Note: this was written before Gucci Gang got popular. The editors regret the reduction of pyramidality that resulted.

tossups.question: This leader was taped giving orders to the head of the SDS to follow the RAM plan for providing arms to certain militias. This leader organized protests called “rallies of truth” to replace provincial leaders with his supporters, as part of his “anti-bureaucratic revolution.” This leader’s country was the target of Operation Noble Anvil, which saw a mistaken bombing of a Chinese embassy. With Alija Izetbegović and Franjo Tudjman, this leader signed the (*) Dayton Agreement. A vehicle operator charged into the RTS building during the Bulldozer Revolution, which led to this leader’s overthrow. The KLA fought against this leader’s government for the autonomy of Kosovo. For 10 points, name this leader, the president of Serbia during the Bosnian War.

An overture named for one of these events was written as the “Life” section of a set of three pieces based on “Nature, Life, and Love” and was composed by Dvořák. One piece titled for one of these events was inspired by a “mourning waltz” composed by Schubert, and has movements depicting figures such as Frederic Chopin and Ernestine von Fricken. That piece named for one of these events contains a recurring motif representing von Fricken’s hometown of (*) Asch, spelled A-S-C-H. A suite titled after one of these events includes a movement that features a series of scales meant to mock the pianists playing them, and also features a cello solo in its movement “The Swan.” For 10 points, name these festivals which inspired Schumann’s Opus 9 and a suite by Saint-Saëns titled after the animals it depicts.

A book which portrays this event includes a character who warns Igor about an investment scam, for which he rewards her with ice cream. In that same book which portrays this event, Maxime investigates a security firm headed by Gabriel Ice. As a result of this historical event, Justin steals a pair of binoculars to keep a watch for a man he believes is named “Bill Lawton.” In that book, Keith Neudecker grabs the wrong briefcase during this event and watches a reenactment performed by the title (*) performance artist. Nine year old Oskar Schell must discover what a key unlocks after his father was killed during this event in a novel by Jonathan Safran Foer. For 10 points, name this recent historical event, which has been portrayed in such works as Bleeding Edge, Falling Man, and Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close.

In a dialogue written by this thinker, Kate describes the “commercial” and “guardian” moral syndromes, which can combine to form a “monstrous moral hybrid.” This thinker used 19th century Japanese bicycle manufacturing to illustrate the concept of import replacement. A book by this thinker argues that innovation benefits urban centers at the expense of rural areas, and that people should buy local. This thinker opposed Robert (*) Moses’s LOMEX, a proposed expressway that would have passed through Greenwich Village. This thinker criticized orthodox urban planning in a book that, amid a discussion of sidewalks, notes the roles of “eyes on the street” in ensuring safety. For 10 points, name this author of The Death and Life of Great American Cities.

Diagrams useful for visualizing this quantity were introduced by Jucys. One object useful in calculations with this quantity is defined such that the sum over three copies of this quantity is zero, and is frequently written as a two-by-three array. In a basis of eigenstates of this quantity, elements of irreducible tensor operators are proportional to (*) Clebsch-Gordan coefficients, which are used to calculate couplings of this quantity. The components of this quantity commute with the square of this quantity, but not with each other. The magnetic quantum number corresponds to one component of this quantity, while the orbital quantum number corresponds to this quantity’s magnitude. For 10 points name this quantity, the product of moment of inertia and angular velocity.
tossups.answer: angular momentum [prompt on spin; do NOT accept or prompt on just “momentum” or “linear momentum”]

tossups.question: During negotiations for the Treaty of Versailles, this man led a fact-finding mission to Hungary’s communist government. Troops under this man’s command took the lead during the Battle of Delville Wood. This man played a key role in creating the League of Nations, which awarded his country direct control over the city of Walvis (*) Bay. This man’s lukewarm support for segregation, coupled with heavy gerrymandering, cost him his last election against Daniel Francois Malan, the leader of the National Party. After fighting on the losing side during the Boer War, this man founded a political party to advocate for Afrikaner rights. For 10 points, name this final pre-Apartheid South African leader, an Afrikaner former general.

One poet with this surname created a project called “Printing out the Internet,” which filled a gallery with ten tons of paper. That poet with this surname was widely criticized for creating a found poem out of an autopsy report for his “The Body of Michael Brown.” A quote from a different poet with this surname provides the title of Tony Judt’s book Ill Fares the Land. That passage goes on to state that “a bold peasantry, their country's pride, / When once destroyed, can never be supplied.” An author with this surname wrote about Sophia being rescued from (*) drowning by Mr. Burchell in a novel where Olivia fakes her death and obtains her marriage license to Squire Thornhill. For 10 points, give the shared surname of conceptual poet Kenneth, and the author of “The Deserted Village” and The Vicar of Wakefield, Oliver.

Simon Jarvis considered one text by this author to form a “philosophical materialism,” and this author said that text tried to “break through the deception of constitutive reality.” This thinker thought that experience is possible by that which exceeds thought and sensibility, and this thinker refers to the excess as “das Nichtidentische,” or the non-identical. With Princeton sociologist Paul Lazarsfeld, this philosopher found a change in the music in late capitalism,(*) which he wrote about in “On the Fetish-Character in Music and the Regression of Listening.” This teacher of Habermas wrote a critique of modernity, in which he and another author argue that people willfully follow fascist ideology and includes a chapter called “The Culture Industry.” For 10 points, name this Frankfurt school philosopher who worked with Horkheimer on The Dialectic of Enlightenment.

One mountain range named for this color spans most of the length of Bhutan, while another mountain range named for this color covers most of Powys and Monmouthshire in Wales. It’s not blue, but a subrange of the Appalachian Mountains named for this color is located in Western (*) North Carolina. The largest tributary on the Amazon’s left bank is named for this color, as is a landform whose indigenous name is paha sapa. Ports such as Guria and Trabzon are located on a sea named for this color, and a nation with its capital at Podgorica is named for a mountain of this color. The seas of Azov and Marmara are marginal seas of a sea named for, for 10 points, what color?
tossups.answer: black [accept negro; or crna; or qara]

tossups.question: A rather morbid author with this surname, who became known as the “demonic talent,” described trading an artifact for a new basket in “Finding an Arrowhead on an Old Battlefield.” Another author with this surname wrote “Someday … I will tell you how I remembered you / Tonight on the stormy mountain” in the poem “When Will I Be Home.” The best known poet with this surname wrote “You ask why I live in these green mountains. I smile. I can’t answer.” in one poem, and compared bright (*) moonlight to frost on the ground in another. That author with this surname dances with his shadow in the poem “Drinking Alone Under the Moon.” For 10 points, give the surname shared by Mao Zedong’s three favourite poets, a trio of Tang-dynasty authors with given names He, Shangyin, and Bai.

(TB) This ruler’s illegitimate daughter Felice became independently wealthy through her castle at Palo and held the title of Orsini Signora after she married Gian Giordano Orsini. This ruler rewarded financial support from Agostino Chigi by making him treasurer and notary of the Apostolic Camera. After the death of Prince Arthur, Henry (*) VII successfully requested a dispensation from this pope for Henry VIII to marry Catherine of Aragon. This pope, who founded the Swiss Guard, created the League of Cambrai to oppose Venice. Sculptures carved for this pope’s tomb included Dying Slave, Rebellious Slave, and a horned Moses, all of which were works by Michelangelo. For 10 points, name this “Warrior Pope,” who commissioned the decoration of the Sistine Chapel ceiling.
tossups.answer: Julius II [or Giuliano della Rovere] <Ed. JM> Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: In the novel Jailbird, this fictional character is shown as the only American convicted of treason during the Korean War. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this fictional author, who causes Dwayne Hoover to go berserk after arriving in Midland City upon the request of his greatest fan, Eliot Rosewater.
Kilgore Trout appears in many novels, such as Galápagos, Breakfast of Champions, and Slaughterhouse-Five, which were all written by this American author.

This fictional painter of The Temptation of Saint Anthony appears in the bar where Trout meets Hoover in Breakfast of Champions, and also serves as the narrator and protagonist of Vonnegut’s later novel Bluebeard.

bonuses.leadin: Hugh Mundy exposed a scandal regarding one of these institutions, whose inmates were so hungry that they were found eating marrow from the bones that they were supposed to be crushing for fertilizer. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these institutions, where people had to reside to receive relief from the government under the Poor Law Amendment Act of 1834. These institutions were colloquially known as “spikes.”
Instituting the Workhouse system involved the abolition of this system, which allowed the poor to collect alms without going into workhouses.

The last remnants of the workhouse system were abolished by the National Assistance Act of 1948, which was passed during the ministry of Clement Attlee, a leader of this democratic socialist political party.

bonuses.leadin: In a work co-written with Whitehead, this philosopher proves one plus one equals two, and then remarks “The above proposition is occasionally useful.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this English philosopher and coauthor of the Principia Mathematica, who also created a namesake teapot about the existence of God.
Russell also wrote this essay, in which he characterizes the title kinds of phrases “solely in virtue of [their] form”. It also posits a descriptivist theory of names.

In “On Denoting”, Russell describes this thinker’s theory of objects by referencing the “present King of France” and “the round square,” before insisting that those objects violate the principle of contradiction.

bonuses.leadin: No speech is audible during this film’s opening scene, during which Bill kills his supervisor in a steel mill. For 10 points:
parts: Name this Terrence Mallick film, in which Bill’s girlfriend Abby marries a sick farmer to claim his riches, but gradually starts to fall in love with him.

Almost all of Days of Heaven was shot by cinematographer Nestor Almendros during this period of time just before sundown. Give the term used for this period, not the actual times at which it begins and ends.
In a notable scene in Days of Heaven, helicopters were used to scatter seeds and peanut shells in order to depict a swarm of these animals devouring a wheat field.

bonuses.leadin: The non-integrability of this problem was first demonstrated by Poincaré, though he initially mistakenly thought he had proven the opposite. For 10 points each:
answers: gravitational three-body problem [prompt on n-body problem]
harmonic oscillator potential [or spring potential; or r2 potential]
parts: Name this physics problem, which centers around determining the orbits of a certain number of celestial objects. When the mass of one object is small, it can remain stationary at Lagrange points.

Unlike the three-body problem, the two-body central potential problem is trivially solvable for all potentials. By Bertrand’s theorem, however, only the gravitational potential and this other potential have the property that all bound orbits are closed.
For a system with n degrees of freedom, integrability is equivalent to the system having at least this many independent conserved quantities. Your answer should be in terms of n.

bonuses.leadin: Justinian the Great had some pretty good advisors, so answer questions about them. For 10 points each:
parts: This financial advisor and Praetorian prefect implemented new taxes that helped fund Justinian’s military adventures. He was dismissed after feuding with Belisarius.
Tribonian, among other scholars, wrote the Corpus Juris Civilis, one of these documents, another of which was promulgated by Napoleon.
This Armenian eunuch conducted successful campaigns in Northern Italy, including the siege of Ravenna. Upon his firing, Theodora unkindly told him to “go spin thread with the women.”

bonuses.leadin: The title character of this novel tyrannizes his sister for years, and then hangs himself in front of her house when she breaks away from him. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this Thomas Bernhard novel about the pianist Wertheimer, who auctions off his piano after realizing he could never play as well as his friend Glenn Gould.

Like many characters created by Thomas Bernhard, the narrator of The Loser has a very unfavourable opinion of this country. Upon his death, Bernhard infamously willed that none of his works ever be sold or staged in this home country of his, which also produced Stefan Zweig and is the second largest market for German literature.
This other Austrian author also used stream of consciousness to write about a repressed piano player in her novel The Piano Teacher. Her 2016 play Rage is about the Charlie Hebdo massacre.

bonuses.leadin: This process happens after the Cori cycle acts on lactic acid. For 10 points each:
answers: Pompe’s disease [or glycogen storage disease type 2; or GSD 2; or alpha-1,4-glucosidase deficiency; or acid maltase deficiency disease; or AMD; or GAA deficiency] <Ed. JS>
parts: Name this process, which occurs primarily in the liver and kidneys and results in production of monosaccharides. Unlike a related process, this process has an oxaloacetate intermediate.
Blood glucose levels can also be increased by the breakdown of this starch-like polysaccharide by debranching enzymes and a namesake phosphorylase.

In this disorder, which results in myopathy and cardiorespiratory problems, the lysosome cannot process glycogen. This autosomal recessive disorder is caused by mutations in the acid alpha-glucosidase gene.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions related to spears in the mythology of the British Isles. For 10 points each:
answers: the Fisher King [or Pelles; or Anfortas]
Gronwy Pebr Lord of Penllyn (graw-noo , but be lenient on pronunciation) [also accept Goronwy] <Ed. HB>
parts: This hero of the Ulster Cycle fought using the spear Gáe Bulg and battled against Connacht during the Cattle-Raid of Cooley.

The Holy Grail was guarded by this man, who suffered from a spear wound to the leg, or possibly groin. Because Percival did not ask the healing question to this man, this “Wounded King” was unable to recover.

In the fourth branch of the Mabinogion, this man forges a spear, which he uses to impale Lleu Llaw Gyffes under the advice of Lleu’s wife Blodeuwedd. Lleu then transforms into an eagle, returning later to kill this man with a spear.

bonuses.leadin: In 1895, the Japanese ambassador Miura Goro sent a group of assassins to kill this monarch with the aid of the Japanese-trained Hullyeondae Regiment. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this monarch, the wife of Gojong, who opposed Japanese influence in her country. This monarch lent her support to the establishment of the Ewha Womans University by the American missionary Mary F. Scranton.
Min was the queen of this East Asian country, which was ruled by the Joseon dynasty prior to this country’s annexation by Japan in 1910.

Another prominent East Asian female monarch of the late 19th century was this Chinese empress dowager, who served as a regent for the Guangxu Emperor. She forcefully ended the Hundred Days’ Reform with a coup in 1898.

bonuses.leadin: The “secondary,” or “nonclustering,” type of these data structures are built on a search key that does not define the sequential order of the file, unlike the “primary” or “clustering” type. For 10 points each:
answers: trees [or B+ trees; or binary search trees]
parts: Name these data structures, which are used to speed up lookups in a database by storing the values of a search key and a pointer to records with the same search key.

A common way to implement an index makes use of the B+ (“B plus”) type of these data structures. The “binary search” type of these data structures allows you to search, insert, and delete sorted data in log n time.
B+ trees always have this property, like AVL trees and red-black trees, which fall under a class of trees that automatically attempt to keep their heights as low as possible at all times.

bonuses.leadin: During these riots, a group of off-duty police officers called the “Vengeance Squad” attempted to enact vigilante justice after a group of sailors were allegedly attacked by Mexicans. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these riots that took place in the summer of 1943, which saw servicemen attack Mexican-American youths who wore the namesake outfits that violated rationing regulations.
The Zoot Suit Riots took place in this California city, which was also the site of riots in 1992 after a group of four white policemen were acquitted of charges related to the beating of Rodney King.

Prior to the Zoot Suit Riots, racial tensions were inflamed by this crime that led to the death of José Díaz. Seventeen Mexican-American youths were racially profiled and found guilty in a mass trial for this crime.

bonuses.leadin: This piece was originally written with a viola solo for Paganini, but the dedicatee rejected it for being “too full of rests.” For 10 points each:
answers: Harold en Italie [or Harold in Italy; accept but DO NOT READ “Hector Berlioz’s second symphony” or equivalents]
Grande symphonie funèbre et triomphale [or Grand Funereal and Triumphal Symphony; prompt on Hector Berlioz’s fourth symphony or equivalents]
parts: Name this symphony, which concludes with a fourth-movement “Orgy of the Brigands.”
Harold en Italie was written by this French Romantic composer of La damnation de Faust and Symphonie fantastique.
This final Berlioz symphony was written to commemorate the lives lost during the July Revolution. Some sources claim that Berlioz conducted this symphony with a sword rather than a baton.

bonuses.leadin: The standard for this type of reaction is set by hydrogen and platinum. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of half reaction, in which one species gains an electron, unlike oxidation.

These diagrams named for an American chemist summarize standard electrode potentials for a given element, with the most highly oxidized compound on the left. Arrows representing possible reductions connect the compounds on these diagrams.

A Latimer diagram can be used to construct a diagram of this name, which shows the free energy for different oxidation states of a species. In organic chemistry, a “circle” with this name shows bonding and antibonding molecular orbitals, and can be used to determine whether or not a molecule is aromatic.

bonuses.leadin: In one story from this collection, a photograph of an 17 ¾ inch African pygmy called Little Flower causes consternation when is published in the newspaper. For 10 points,
parts: Name this collection which includes “The Smallest Woman in the World,” “The Chicken,” and “Daydreams of a Drunk Woman.” In its title story, Catherine’s mother departs from awkwardly from a visit after insulting Catherine’s husband and son.
Family Ties was written by Clarice Lispector, a Jewish immigrant to this country. Other short story writers from this country include Mario de Andrade and Machado de Assis.

In Lispector’s short story “Love,” Ana has an epiphany upon watching a gum-chewing person with this characteristic. A bearded person with this characteristic helps lead the narrator to an epiphany in Raymond Carver’s story “Cathedral.”

bonuses.leadin: Modern love is an enduring subject in popular music, so answer some questions about references to it, for 10 points each.
parts: This English band, fronted by Kele Okereke, included a track titled “This Modern Love” on its 2005 release Silent Alarm, which was apparently featured on How I Met Your Mother. You may be more familiar with their song “Helicopter.”

In the 70s, The Modern Lovers released a song about this figure, who “could walk down your street and girls could not resist his stare.” Thought not Tom Ford, a Jay-Z song named for this artist appears on Magna Carta Holy Grail.
This singer included the song “Modern Love” on his album Let’s Dance. He also recorded “Heroes.”

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the economics of fossil fuels.
answers: taxes [accept Pigouvian taxes; or sin taxes]
IPCC [or Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, prompt on “UN”] <Ed. HB>
parts: In The Coal Question, this economist described a namesake paradox, in which a resource is consumed more as it is used more efficiently. This economist, along with Menger and Walras, contributed to the “marginal revolution.”
Greg Mankiw founded the “Pigou Club” to advocate these policies on gasoline. These policies, which may also be placed on cigarettes, can internalize negative externalities by raising prices.

Biophysical economist Graham Palmer believes that the economy is too dependent on fossil fuels to change as dramatically as the result of this climate science body projects it will. This body says that a decrease in consumption due to decarbonization of 3-11 percentage points is acceptable.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about notable depictions of illness in visual art.
answers: Christina from Christina’s World [accept Christina Olson]
parts: This triptych was painted for a German monastery which specialized in caring for people with skin diseases. Painter Matthias Grunewald depicted Jesus with sores similar to those of the afflicted, emphasizing their shared pain.

This figure is often described as having polio, but accounts from her family indicate that her condition developed gradually since her birth. She has more recently been suggested to have Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, a genetic condition which damages the peripheral nervous system.

This female photographer shot a picture of activist David Kirby surrounded by family on his deathbed, titled “The Face of AIDS.” Published in TIME magazine in 1990, it is considered an important milestone in public perception of the disease.

bonuses.leadin: This man made most of his living off law books, which he had the only patent in England to print. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 16th-century publisher better known for his contributions to literature, whose namesake Miscellany was the first poetry anthology published in English.
This author of “Alas madam for stealing of a kiss” was prominently featured in Tottel’s Miscellany. He also adapted one of Petrarch’s sonnets into the poem “Whoso list to hunt.”
Tottel also published this man’s “Dialogue of Comfort Against Tribulation.” This man is the principal character in Robert Bolt’s play A Man for All Seasons, and he also wrote Utopia.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about people who are mocked in Buddhist scriptures. For 10 points each:
answers: Heart Sutra [or Heart of the Perfection of Wisdom Sutra; or Prajñāpāramitāhṛdaya Sutra]
parts: In the Vinaya Pitaka, the Buddha declared that this man, his cousin, was “controlled by eight wrong conditions” and “doomed to the Downfall, to Niraya Hell,” after he led 500 other monks into a schism within the Sangha.
Sariputra, a disciple of the Buddha often regarded as dull in Mahayana tradition, is the addressee of this sutra, which is the origin of the mantra, “Gone, gone, gone beyond, gone completely beyond.”

Nichiren, a Buddhist leader from this country, mocked this country’s other Buddhist movements with his “four declarations,” which included such tolerant statements as “Nembutsu is hell” and “the Zen are devils.”
